statement.text: Angular momentum IS quantized in units of ℏ = 1.055 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s. The smallest nonzero angular momentum is ℏ/2 (spin-1/2 particles like electrons). This is a TRUE quantum minimum—there is no angular momentum smaller than ℏ/2 except zero. The Planck angular momentum is also ℏ (by definition), so for this quantity, the Planck unit IS the fundamental quantum of action.
statement.formal: Minimum nonzero: L_min = ℏ/2 = 5.27 × 10⁻³⁵ J·s (spin-1/2); Photon spin: ℏ; Planck: ℏ = 1.055 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s

explanation.intuition: Angular momentum is one quantity where the Planck unit (ℏ) IS the fundamental quantum. All angular momenta are integer or half-integer multiples of ℏ. The minimum nonzero value is ℏ/2 for fermions (spin-1/2). This is a TRUE quantum limit—not just a measurement limit, but a property of nature.
explanation.key_insight: For angular momentum, unlike most other quantities, the Planck/natural unit IS the minimum. L = nℏ/2 where n = 0, 1, 2, 3... This quantization emerges from quantum mechanics and is exact. Measurement of spin with precision better than ℏ/2 is meaningless—spin eigenvalues are exactly ±ℏ/2.

comparison_with_planck.interpretation: Planck angular momentum IS the natural unit. This is the one case where Planck sets the fundamental scale.

related.relationship: Planck angular momentum = ℏ (same as quantum)
ℏ is both Planck unit and quantum of action

learning_objectives: Understand angular momentum quantization in units of ℏ
Know that ℏ/2 is the minimum nonzero angular momentum
Recognize this is the one quantity where Planck unit IS the minimum
common_misconceptions: Angular momentum CAN be zero (spin-0 particles exist)
The minimum NONZERO value is ℏ/2, not ℏ
This is a TRUE quantum limit, not just a measurement limit
